prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISP9_73 CO5-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect the CO5-4 transition in target WISP9_73

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 5-4 transition for WISP9_73 (z=1.454) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al. in prep).
CO line intensities are used to estimate the signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for the given sensitivity. This sensitivity is chosen to ensure a <30% total overhead, and a >5 sigma detection. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the S/N is ~23 for CO 5-4 with a line width of 80 km/s. By requesting a frequency width of 50 km/s the CO line emission may be partially resolved. Also, the requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of ~1.1 kpc at z~1.5, making the half-light radii partially resolvable (Re ~ 1.5 kpc). The `Total overheads' in this setting is 25%.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISP25_53 CO5-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect the CO5-4transition in target WISP25_53

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 5-4 transition for WISP25_53 (z=1.486) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al. in prep).
CO line intensities are used to estimate the signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for the given sensitivity. This sensitivity is chosen to ensure a <30% total overhead, and a >5 sigma detection. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the S/N is ~12 for CO 5-4 with a line width of 80 km/s. By requesting a frequency width of 50 km/s the CO line emission may be partially resolved. Also, the requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of ~1.1 kpc at z~1.5, making the half-light radii partially resolvable (Re ~ 2.2 kpc). The `Total overheads' in this setting is 25%.

CO line intensities are used to estimate the signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for the given sensitivity. This sensitivity is chosen to ensure a <30% total overhead, and a >5 sigma detection. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISP9_73 CO3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect the CO3-2 transition in target WISP9_73

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 3-2 transition for WISP9_73 (z=1.454) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al. in prep).
CO line intensities are used to estimate the signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for the given sensitivity. This sensitivity is chosen to ensure a <30% total overhead, and a >5 sigma detection. With the selected sensitivity of 0.30 mJy, the S/N is ~17 for CO 3-2 with a line width of 80 km/s, and a requested frequency width of the same value. The `Total overheads' in this setting is 24%.

This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 3-2 transition for WISP46_75 (z=1.504) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al. in prep).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
There is strong disagreement between observations and theoretical predictions for the evolution of the molecular gas fraction. The large uncertainties in M(H2) at high-z are probably partially responsible for this tension. Genzel et al. (2012) recently showed that commonly used values for the CO-->H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO, valid for local MW-like and starburst galaxies) may result in a significant underestimate of the real H2 mass, due to a much higher alpha-CO at lower metallicities. Covering a small range of metallicity, Genzel et al. could not accurately constrain the slope of the alpha_CO-Z relation.
In this program, we propose to extend the Genzel et al. measurements to galaxies with a factor of two lower metallicities. We request 6.6 hours, to observe three z~1.5 galaxies in the CO(3-2 and 5-4) emission lines. The targets have well constrained oxygen abundances, stellar masses and SFRs. Together with available HST imaging in multiple bands, the proposed observations will allow us to measure: 1) alpha-CO in low-mass, low metallicity galaxies, 2) the molecular-gas depletion rate, 3) the neutral gas mass fraction, and 4) the dynamical mass using the CO line width.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
